reverse_problem: Given \( \ell^2 = 245 \), determine the characteristics of the linear functions \( f(x), g(x), h(x) \) such that the graph of \( y = k(x) \) for \( -3.5 \le x \le 3.5 \) has a length of \( \sqrt{245} \).
reverse_solution_process:
1. Assume \( f(x) = ax + b, g(x) = cx + d, h(x) = ex + f \).
2. Given that \( k(x) = \min\{f(x), g(x), h(x)\} \), the graph length over the interval \( -3.5 \le x \le 3.5 \) is \( \sqrt{245} \).
3. Suppose the graph of \( k(x) \) consists of two line segments with slopes \( \pm 2 \). The total length is \( \sqrt{7^2 + (2 \cdot 7)^2} = \sqrt{245} \).
4. Thus, we can determine the specific forms and behaviors of \( f(x), g(x), h(x) \) over the interval.
reverse_solution: Based on assumptions and calculations, the specific linear functions \( f(x), g(x), h(x) \) can be determined to match the given conditions for the graph length of \( k(x) \).
source_question: "Suppose $f(x),g(x),h(x)$ are all linear functions, and $j(x)$ and $k(x)$ are defined by $$j(x) = \max\{f(x),g(x),h(x)\},$$$$k(x) = \min\{f(x),g(x),h(x)\}.$$This means that, for each $x$, we define $j(x)$ to be equal to either $f(x),$ $g(x),$ or $h(x),$ whichever is greatest; similarly, $k(x)$ is the least of these three values.Shown below is the graph of $y=j(x)$ for $-3.5\le x\le 3.5$.Let $\ell$ be the length of the graph of $y=k(x)$ for $-3.5\le x\le 3.5$. What is the value of $\ell^2$?[asy]size(150);real ticklen=3;real tickspace=2;real ticklength=0.1cm;real axisarrowsize=0.14cm;pen axispen=black+1.3bp;real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm;real tickdown=-0.5;real tickdownlength=-0.15inch;real tickdownbase=0.3;real wholetickdown=tickdown;void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {import graph;real i;if(complexplane) {label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE);label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW);} else {label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5));label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2));}ylimits(ybottom,ytop);xlimits( xleft, xright);real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry;for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArrx.push(i);}}for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArry.push(i);}}if(usegrid) {xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true);yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);}if(useticks) {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));} else {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));}};rr_cartesian_axes(-5,5,-5,5);draw((-3.5,5)--(-2,2)--(2,2)--(3.5,5),red+1.25);dot((-2,2),red);dot((2,2),red);[/asy]"
output: "The graphs of $f(x),g(x),h(x)$ are all lines, and we have a segment of each, so we can extend these segments to form the superimposed graphs of $f(x),$ $g(x),$ and $h(x)$ on one set of axes:[asy]size(150);real ticklen=3;real tickspace=2;real ticklength=0.1cm;real axisarrowsize=0.14cm;pen axispen=black+1.3bp;real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm;real tickdown=-0.5;real tickdownlength=-0.15inch;real tickdownbase=0.3;real wholetickdown=tickdown;void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {import graph;real i;if(complexplane) {label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE);label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW);} else {label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5));label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2));}ylimits(ybottom,ytop);xlimits( xleft, xright);real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry;for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArrx.push(i);}}for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArry.push(i);}}if(usegrid) {xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true);yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);}if(useticks) {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));} else {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));}};rr_cartesian_axes(-5,5,-5,5);draw((-3.5,5)--(1.5,-5),red+1.25);draw((3.5,5)--(-1.5,-5),red+1.25);draw((-5,2)--(5,2),red+1.25);[/asy]The graph of $k(x)$ consists of the "bottom surface" of this tangle of lines, shown here in light blue:[asy]size(150);real ticklen=3;real tickspace=2;real ticklength=0.1cm;real axisarrowsize=0.14cm;pen axispen=black+1.3bp;real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm;real tickdown=-0.5;real tickdownlength=-0.15inch;real tickdownbase=0.3;real wholetickdown=tickdown;void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {import graph;real i;if(complexplane) {label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE);label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW);} else {label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5));label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2));}ylimits(ybottom,ytop);xlimits( xleft, xright);real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry;for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArrx.push(i);}}for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) {if(abs(i) >0.1) {TicksArry.push(i);}}if(usegrid) {xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true);yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);}if(useticks) {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));} else {xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));}};rr_cartesian_axes(-5,5,-5,5);draw((-3.5,5)--(1.5,-5),red+1.25);draw((3.5,5)--(-1.5,-5),red+1.25);draw((-5,2)--(5,2),red+1.25);draw((-1.5,-5)--(0,-2)--(1.5,-5),cyan+1.5);[/asy]Both pieces of the graph of $y=k(x)$ have slope $\pm 2$, so the total length of this graph along the interval $-3.5\le x\le 3.5$ is $\sqrt{7^2+(2\cdot 7)^2} = \sqrt{245}$. Therefore, $\ell^2=\boxed{245}$."

reverse_problem: Given that the sum of two positive consecutive integers is 45, find their product.
reverse_solution_process:
1. Let the two positive consecutive integers be \(x\) and \(x+1\).
2. Given their sum \(x + (x+1) = 45\), we can solve for \(x\).
3. Simplifying the equation gives \(2x + 1 = 45\).
4. Subtract 1 from both sides to get \(2x = 44\).
5. Divide by 2 to find \(x = 22\).
6. The two integers are 22 and 23.
7. Their product is \(22 \cdot 23\).
reverse_solution: The product of the two integers is \(22 \cdot 23 = 506\).
source_question: "The product of two positive consecutive integers is 506. What is their sum?"
output: "We are given that $x(x+1) = 506$, so $x^2 + x = 506$, which means $x^2 + x - 506 =0$.  The prime factorization of $506$ is $2\cdot 11 \cdot 23$, so we see that the quadratic factors as $(x + 23)(x-22)=0$.  The positive solution is $x=22$, so the two numbers are 22 and 23.  Their sum is $22+23 = \boxed{45}$."

reverse_problem: Given that the sum of two positive consecutive integers is 45, find their product.
reverse_solution_process:
1. Let the two positive consecutive integers be \(x\) and \(x+1\).
2. Given their sum \(x + (x+1) = 45\), we can solve for \(x\).
3. Simplifying the equation gives \(2x + 1 = 45\).
4. Subtract 1 from both sides to get \(2x = 44\).
5. Divide by 2 to find \(x = 22\).
6. The two integers are 22 and 23.
7. Their product is \(22 \cdot 23\).
reverse_solution: The product of the two integers is \(22 \cdot 23 = 506\).
source_question: "When the square root of $x$ is cubed, the answer is 64. What is the value of $x$?"
output: "We have $(\sqrt{x})^3=64$ and solve for $x$. $$x^\frac{3}{2}=64\qquad\Rightarrow x=64^\frac{2}{3}=(64^\frac{1}{3})^2=4^2=16$$The value of $x$ is $\boxed{16}$."

reverse_problem: Given that \( \left( \frac{1}{2k} \right)^{-2} \cdot (-k)^n = -4k^5 \), find the value of \(n\).
reverse_solution_process:
1. Simplify \( \left(  rac{1}{2k} ight)^{-2} \) to get \((2k)^2\).
2. Combine this with \((-k)^n\), giving us \((2k)^2 \cdot (-k)^n\).
3. This simplifies to \(4k^2 \cdot (-k)^n\).
4. Combine the powers of \(k\) to get \(4k^{2+n} \cdot (-1)^n\).
5. Set this equal to \(-4k^5\) and solve for \(n\).
reverse_solution: Matching powers of \(k\), we get \(2+n=5\), so \(n=3\).

reverse_problem: Given \(a=4\), \(b=13\), and \(c=3\), find \(d\) such that \((2^{a \Delta b}) \Delta (3^{c \Delta d}) = -17\).
reverse_solution_process:
1. Start with the expression \((2^{a \Delta b}) \Delta (3^{c \Delta d}) = -17\).
2. Substitute the given values \(a=4\), \(b=13\), and \(c=3\).
3. Calculate \(a \Delta b = 4 \Delta 13 = 4^2 - 13 = 3\).
4. Let \(d\) be the unknown value and express \(c \Delta d\).
5. Solve for \(d\) such that \((2^3) \Delta (3^{c \Delta d}) = -17\).
6. Calculate the remaining part to find \(d\).
reverse_solution:
To find \(d\):
- Given \(a=4\), \(b=13\), \(c=3\).
- Calculate \(a \Delta b = 4 \Delta 13 = 4^2 - 13 = 3\).
- \(3^{c \Delta d} = 3^{3 \Delta d}\).
- We know \((2^3) \Delta (3^{3 \Delta d}) = -17\), so:
\[ 2^6 - 3^{3 \Delta d} = -17 \]
- This simplifies to:
\[ 64 - 3^{3 \Delta d} = -17 \]
- Solving for \(3^{3 \Delta d}\):
\[ 3^{3 \Delta d} = 81 \]
- Thus:
\[ 3 \Delta d = 4 \]
- Solve for \(d\):
\[ 3^2 - d = 4 \]
\[ 9 - d = 4 \]
\[ d = 5 \]
So, \(d =  oxed{5}\).
source_question: "Define $a \Delta b = a^2 -b $.  What is the value of $ (2^{4 \Delta13})\Delta(3^{3\Delta5})$"

reverse_problem: Given that the simplified result of the expression \(\frac{2^{n+4} - k(2^n)}{2(2^{n+3})}\) is \(\frac{7}{8}\), find the value of \(k\).
reverse_solution_process:
1. Start with the given simplified result \( rac{7}{8}\).
2. Recall the modified expression \( rac{2^{n+4} - k(2^n)}{2(2^{n+3})}\).
3. Set up the equation to equate the modified expression with the simplified result.
4. Solve for \(k\).
reverse_solution:
1. Given the simplified form \( rac{7}{8}\), set up the equation:
   \[ rac{2^{n+4} - k(2^n)}{2(2^{n+3})} =  rac{7}{8}\]
2. Simplify the left-hand side:
   \[ rac{2^{n+4} - k(2^n)}{2^{n+4}} =  rac{7}{8}\]
   \[ rac{2^{n+4} - k \cdot 2^n}{2^{n+4}} =  rac{7}{8}\]
3. Cancel the common factor \(2^n\) in the numerator and denominator:
   \[ rac{2^4 - k}{2 \cdot 2^3} =  rac{7}{8}\]
   \[ rac{16 - k}{16} =  rac{7}{8}\]
4. Solve for \(k\):
   \[16 - k = 14\]
   \[k = 2\]
source_question: "Simplify: $\frac{2^{n+4} - 2(2^n)}{2(2^{n+3})}$. Express your answer as a common fraction."

reverse_problem: Given that Shea buys 13.5 pounds of corn, how many total pounds of corn and beans did she buy if the total cost is $18.09 and beans cost 45 cents per pound?
reverse_solution_process:
1. Let $c = 13.5$ be the number of pounds of corn.
2. The price of corn is 99 cents per pound.
3. Let $b$ be the number of pounds of beans.
4. Set up the equation for the total cost: $99c + 45b = 1809$.
5. Solve for $b$.
reverse_solution:
1. Given $c = 13.5$, the cost of corn is $99 \cdot 13.5 = 1336.5$ cents.
2. The total cost is 1809 cents, so the cost of beans is $1809 - 1336.5 = 472.5$ cents.
3. Since beans cost 45 cents per pound, $b =  rac{472.5}{45} = 10.5$ pounds.
4. The total number of pounds of corn and beans is $c + b = 13.5 + 10.5 = 24$.
source_question: "Corn costs 99 cents per pound, and beans cost 45 cents per pound. If Shea buys 24 total pounds of corn and beans, and it costs $\$18.09$, how many pounds of corn did Shea buy? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest tenth."
output: "Let $c$ and $b$ be the number of pounds of corn and beans Shea buys, respectively. We can turn the givens into a two-variable, linear system: \begin{align*}b+c&=24\\45b+99c&=1809\end{align*} We can multiply the first equation by 45 and subtract it from the second to get $(99-45)c=1809-45(24)$, which reduces to $54c=729$ or $c=13.5$. So Shea buys $\boxed{13.5\text{ pounds}}$ of corn."

reverse_problem: Given the expression \(\dfrac{5^{a}}{5^{b}} = 5^{\frac{2}{15}}\), find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).
reverse_solution_process: 1. We know that \(\dfrac{5^{a}}{5^{b}} = 5^{a-b}\).\n2. Given that \(5^{a-b} = 5^{\frac{2}{15}}\), we can equate the exponents: \(a - b = \frac{2}{15}\).\n3. Solve for \(a\) and \(b\) such that \(a = \frac{1}{3}\) and \(b = \frac{1}{5}\).
reverse_solution: 1. Set \(a = \frac{1}{3}\) and \(b = \frac{1}{5}\).\n2. Check the equation: \(\dfrac{5^{\frac{1}{3}}}{5^{\frac{1}{5}}} = 5^{\frac{1}{3} - \frac{1}{5}} = 5^{\frac{2}{15}}\).\n3. The values of \(a\) and \(b\) that satisfy the given expression are \(\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}\) and \(\boxed{\frac{1}{5}}\).
source_question: "The expression $\dfrac{\sqrt[3]{5}}{\sqrt[5]{5}}$ equals 5 raised to what power?"
output: "We have  \[\dfrac{\sqrt[3]{5}}{\sqrt[5]{5}} = \dfrac{5^{\frac13}}{5^{\frac15}} = 5^{\frac13-\frac15} = 5^{\frac{2}{15}}.\]So, the expression equals 5 raised to the $\boxed{2/15}$ power."

reverse_problem: Given \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\) and \(|x| + |y| = \sqrt{2}\), find the possible values of \(x\) and \(y\).
reverse_solution_process:
1. We are given that \(|x| + |y| = \sqrt{2}\).
2. Assume \(x \ge 0\) and \(y \ge 0\) without loss of generality. Then \(|x| + |y| = x + y\).
3. We also know that \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\).
4. From the original solution, we derived that \(x + y = \sqrt{2}\).
5. Solve for \(x\) and \(y\) such that \(x + y = \sqrt{2}\) and \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\).
reverse_solution:
1. Assume \(x = y\).
2. From \(x + y = \sqrt{2}\), we have \(2x = \sqrt{2}\), so \(x = y =  rac{1}{\sqrt{2}} =  rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\).
3. Verify that \(x^2 + y^2 = \left( rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}ight)^2 + \left( rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}ight)^2 =  rac{2}{4} +  rac{2}{4} = 1\).
4. Therefore, the values of \(x\) and \(y\) are \(x = y =  oxed{ rac{\sqrt{2}}{2}}\).
source_question: "If $x^2+y^2=1$, what is the largest possible value of $|x|+|y|$?"
output: "If $(x,y)$ lies on the circle, so does $(x,-y),$ $(-x,-y),$ and $(-x,-y),$ (which all give the same value of $|x| + |y|$), so we can assume that $x \ge 0$ and $y \ge 0.$Then $|x| + |y| = x + y.$  Squaring, we get\[(x + y)^2 = x^2 + 2xy + y^2 = 1 + 2xy.\]Note that $(x - y)^2 \ge 0.$  Expanding, we get $x^2 - 2xy + y^2 \ge 0,$ so $2xy \le x^2 + y^2 = 1.$  Hence,\[1 + 2xy \le 2,\]which means $x + y \le \sqrt{2}.$  Equality occurs when $x = y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},$ so the maximum value of $|x| + |y|$ is $\boxed{\sqrt{2}}.$"

reverse_problem: Given the ordered pair \((j,k) = (-4, -\frac{1}{2})\), find the constant term \(c\) in the equation \(2k - j = c\).
reverse_solution_process: 1. We are given that \(j = -4\) and \(k = -\frac{1}{2}\).\n2. Substitute these values into the equation \(2k - j = c\).\n3. Calculate \(c\) by evaluating the expression.
reverse_solution:
1. Substitute \(j = -4\) and \(k = - rac{1}{2}\) into the equation:
\[2\left(- rac{1}{2}ight) - (-4) = c.\]
2. Simplify the equation:
\[-1 + 4 = c.\]
3. Thus, the value of \(c\) is  oxed{3}.\
source_question: "Find the ordered pair $(j,k)$ that satisfies the equations $5j-42k=1$ and $2k-j=3$."
output: "We can multiply the second equation by 5, so that our equations are \begin{align*}5j -42k &=1\text{, and} \\-5j +10k &=15. \end{align*}Summing these equations gives $-32k=16$, so $k=-16/32=-1/2$. We substitute this value for $k$ into one of the equations to solve for $j$: \begin{align*}2\left(\frac{-1}{2}\right)-j&=3 \quad \Rightarrow \\ j &= -4.\end{align*}So the solution is $\boxed{(-4,-\frac{1}{2})}$."
